title: A is 40 m South west of B. C is 40m South east of B. Then, C is in which direction of A? - Quora

response.answer_text: Let the divine B be at the origin (0,0) of the cartesian co-ordinate plane. So, Mr.A is 40m south-west of B. The direction south-west suggests that Mr. A is in the 3rd Quadrant of the cartesian system. And as we know, both abscissa & ordinate are negative in the 3rd Quadrant. Therefore, the point where A is standing at (-40Cos45°,-40Sin45°). Mind you, this point is with respect to B’s position and (-40Cos45°, -40Sin45°) are the projections of A’s position on X and Y axes respectively. Now, coming to Mr.C. C is 40m south-east of B. Hence C is in the 4th Quadrant of the x-y plane. And it is known to you that x is positive and y is negative in the 4th Quadrant. Hence, co-ordinate of Mr.C’s position is (40Cos45°, -40Sin45°). Where these trigonometric terms hold the same meaning as mentioned above. And We can notice from here that positions of A and C are images of one another in the y-axis. Therefore, A must move EASTWARDS in order to reach C. And to be precise, C is in east direction to that of A. Friends….! There are 8 main directions recognized as below:  Let us imagine that B is at the centre of all the directions then: A is 40 m South West of B. C is 40 m South East of B. A and C being in two opposite directions are forming equilateral triangle from B, with A and C as base. Thus C is in East direction from A. Answer: C is in East direction from A.
